refnamediv.refpurpose: Assign variables as if they were an array

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Like array, this is not really a function, but a language construct. list is used to assign a list of variables in one operation.

note.para: list only works on numerical arrays and assumes the numerical indices start at 0.

example.title: list examples
example.programlisting:
<?php

$info = array('coffee', 'brown', 'caffeine');

// Listing all the variables
list($drink, $color, $power) = $info;
echo "$drink is $color and $power makes it special.\n";

// Listing some of them
list($drink, , $power) = $info;
echo "$drink has $power.\n";

// Or let's skip to only the third one
list( , , $power) = $info;
echo "I need $power!\n";

?>

warning.para: list assigns the values starting with the right-most parameter. If you are using plain variables, you don't have to worry about this. But if you are using arrays with indices you usually expect the order of the indices in the array the same you wrote in the list from left to right; which it isn't. It's assigned in the reverse order.
